questions.question_text: Which strategy is correct for configuring Spring Security to intercept particular URLs? (Choose the best answer.)

comments.content: yes, the rules for the first matched pattern are used

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
it is important that more specific patterns are defined higher in the list than less specific patterns
A=>most specific rule first and the least specific last.

Selected Answer: D
Quote "A good practice is to define generic rules at the top and more specific rules at the bottom." at https://www.baeldung.com/spring-security-configuring-urls#1-allowing-requests-to-the-products-api

choices.A: The URLs can be specified via configuration (using authorizeRequests () and request matchers), with the most specific rule first and the least specific last.
choices.D: The URLs can be specified via configuration (using authorizeRequests () and request matchers), with the least specific rule first and the most specific last.
choices.C: The URLs are specified in a special properties file, used by Spring Security.
choices.B: Spring Security can obtain URLs from Spring MVC controllers, the Spring Security configuration just needs a reference to the controller to be protected.

questions.question_text: In which three ways are Security filters used in Spring Security? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BDE
- A is incorrect.
- F is incorrect.

Selected Answer: BDE
- A is incorrect. 
- F is incorrect.
- Spring security filter for authorization (What user can do what stuff), not authentication (Who are who?), therefore not for managing application users, causes C is incorrect.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

The above code shows a conditional @Bean method for the creation of a JdbcTemplate bean.
Which two statements correctly describe the code behavior? (Choose two.)

choices.D: A JdbcTemplate bean will be created when the DataSource class is in the classpath but there is no DataSource bean.
choices.B: @ConditionalOnBean(name= “dataSource”) should be replaced with @ConditionalOnMissingBean (DataSource.class) for greater flexibility.
choices.A: @ConditionalOnBean(name= “dataSource”) should be replaced with @ConditionalOnBean (DataSource.class) for greater flexibility.
choices.E: A JdbcTemplate bean will be created when a bean named dataSource has already been created.

discussion.content:
A and E 


Option D is incorrect because the @ConditionalOnBean annotation requires that a bean with the specified name or class already exists in the application context for the JdbcTemplate bean to be created.

Selected Answer: AE
Answer is AE

Selected Answer: AE
Answer is AE

Selected Answer: AE
These are correct

questions.question_text: What is a Spring Boot starter dependency? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
- A is incorrect. 
- B is incorrect, not just runtime, starter need in compile time.
- C is incorrect, it is not an existing pom.xml for downloading.
- D is rationale. Let's see an example https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/blob/main/spring-boot-project/spring-boot-starters/spring-boot-starter-web/build.gradle
D but terrible answer! its a preconfigured set of dependencies
A Spring Boot starter dependency is an easy way to include multiple, coordinated dependencies related to a specific technology, such as web or JDBC

choices.C: A pre-existing model project you can download and use as the basis of your project.
choices.B: A specific POM which you must build to control Spring Boot’s opinionated runtime.
choices.D: An easy way to include multiple, coordinated dependencies related to a specific technology, like web or JDBC.
choices.A: A setting for specifying which code you want Spring Boot to generate for you.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Need 2 things: @EnableTransactionManagement and @Transactional .

Selected Answer: AB
A: You have to enable transaction management.
B: You choose which methods/classes will be treated as transactional by using the @Transactional annotation.

choices.C: A class must be annotated with @Service and @Transaction.
choices.E: Write a Spring AOP advice to implement transactional behavior.
choices.A: Add @EnableTransactionManagement to a Java configuration class.
choices.B: Annotate a class, an interface, or individual methods requiring a transaction with the @Transactional annotation.
choices.D: A class requiring a transaction must implement the TransactionInterceptor interface.

questions.question_text: Which two are required to use transactions in Spring? (Choose two.)
